abstract.p: This is a collection of the materials (outside of the textbook) we will use in class to guide you on your journey through MATH 140. The textbook used in the course will be Calculus: Single Variable, 7th Edition edition by Hughes-Hallett, et al.

introduction.p: This is a collection of the materials (outside of the textbook) we will use in class to guide you on your journey through MATH 140.

section.title: Section 1.7 - Introduction to Continuity and Limits

exercise.p: Are the following functions continuous?
Find k so that the following function is continuous on any interval: f(x) = \left \{ \begin{matrix} kx & x \leq 3 \\ 5 & x > 3 \end{matrix} \right.

solution.p: While I use Desmos for intuition, to find the exact answer we need the left and right sides to meet when x=3. Thus we need k(3)=5 and hence k=\frac 53.

exercise.p: Let f(x) = \frac{e^x - 1}{x}.

ol.li: Make a conjecture (educated guess) about the value of \lim _{x\to 0} f(x) .
Graph the function on your graphing calculator to see if it verifies your conjecture from parts a) and b).

solution.p: We see from both the table and the graph that f(x) approaches 1 as x approaches 0. Hence, \lim_{x\to 0} f(x)=1

section.title: Section 1.8 - Extending the Idea of a Limit

exercise.p: Compute \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{4x+5}{6x^2+7x+8}

solution.p: You can evaluate this graphically, but to me the best tactic is to divide the numerator and denominator by the largest power of x. In this case that is x^2. \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{4x+5}{6x^2+7x+8} = \lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{\frac4x+\frac5{x^2}}{6+\frac7x+\frac8{x^2}} = 0 Note that everything in the numerator goes to zero, so the fraction as a whole goes to zero (as the denominator is nonzero).

exercise.p: Compute the left and right hand limits of the function \frac{\ln(|x|+1)}{x} as x approaches 0 and use these computations to draw a conclusion about \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\ln(|x|+1)}{x}

solution.p: From the left, it appears to be approaching -1, whereas from the right, it appears to be approaching 1. Thus, the limit does not exist.
While any of the solutions can be used here, the algebraic technique is the best choice. \lim_{x\to 2} \frac{x^2-4}{x-2} = \lim_{x\to 2} \frac{(x-2)(x+2)}{(x-2)} = \lim_{x\to 2} x+2 = 4
Here, the algebraic technique cannot be used, so we will use graphical and numerical. From the graph and the table, we see that the limit approaches 1.

section.title: Section 2.1 - How Do We Measure Speed?
Section 2.2 - The Derivative at a Point

exercise.p: Let s(t) represent the distance in inches that a turtle has traveled in t seconds. The table below indicates the position of the turtle at discrete time intervals. \begin{array} {| c | c | c | c | c | c | c | c |} \hline t \text{(in seconds)}& 0 & 0.5 & 1 & 1.5 & 2 & 2.5 & 3 \\ \hline s(t) \text{(in inches)}& 1.2 & 1.5 & 1.7 & 2.0 & 2.3 & 2.4 & 2.7 \\ \hline \end{array} Approximate the instantaneous velocity of the turtle at time t=2.

The following graph is the graph of the position function of a particle traveling in a straight line.
When is the velocity of the particle positive, and when is it negative?

solution.p: The velocity of the particle is positive when the function is increasing, so 0 < t < .75 and t > 2.25. The velocity of the particle is negative when the function is decreasing, so .75 < t < 2.25.

exercise.p: Compute the derivative at a point f'(1) of f(x)=-3x^2+7x-2 using the limit definition of the derivative.
The function f(x) is represented by the graph below. Sketch a graph of f'(x) on the axes below.
If f(x) = x^2 - 4x+5, compute f'(x) using the limit definition of the derivative.
On a hot summer day, Bob takes a carton of ice cream out of a 10^\circF freezer and forgets about it. Suppose room temperature is 75^\circF.

li.p: Sketch a graph of temperature f(t) of the ice cream as a function of time, where t is time in hours.

ol.li: What are the units of f'(t)?
Is the derivative positive or negative?
Interpret the statement f'(4)=3 in the context of the problem.
The units are ^\circF per hour (always output per input)
The derivative is positive as the temperature is increasing
After 4 hours, the temperature of the ice cream is increasing at a rate of 3^\circF per hour.
What can we say about \displaystyle \frac{d^2 s}{dt^2} over this period of time
The second derivative is positive as it appears that the derivative is increasing.

exercise.p: Compute the second derivative of f(x) = 3x^2+7x+1 .
Similar to Example 5 in Section 2.5The following graph is the graph of the position function of a particle traveling in a straight line.

ol.li: When is the acceleration of the particle positive, and when is it negative?
When is the acceleration zero?
The acceleration of the particle is positive when the graph is concave up. This looks to be x>1.5. The acceleration is negative when the graph is concave down. This looks to be x< 1.5.
The acceleration appears to be zero at 1.5

exercise.p: Compute the derivatives of the following functions
A raindrop falls from a cloud with height (in meters) given as a function of time by h=1000-4.9t^2. Find the velocity and acceleration at time t.

solution.p: The velocity is the derivative \frac{dh}{dt} = -9.8 t \text{ m}/\text{sec} and the acceleration is the second derivative \frac{d^2h}{dt^2} = -9.8 \text{ m}/\text{sec}^2

exercise.p: Compute the derivatives of the following functions
Compute the derivatives of the following functions:
Compute the derivatives of the following functions using the chain rule:

So we know that \frac{d}{dx} ( \sin x ) = \cos x \hspace{.2in} \text{ and } \hspace{.2in} \frac{d}{dx} (\cos x) = - \sin x and we know that \tan x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} . Compute the derivative of \tan x.
From problem 62 in section 3.5 The voltage, V, in volts, in an electrical outlet is given as a function of time, t, in second by the function V = 156 \cos(120 \pi t)

ol.li: Give an expression for the rate of change of voltage with respect to time.
What is the maximum rate of change?
The maximum that -\sin(120 \pi t) can be is 1 as -1 is the minimum of the sine function. Thus, the maximum of the derivative here is 156\cdot 120\pi.

exercise.p: Compute the following derivatives:

ol.li: \displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \right) (p.s. Do you know a name for this function?)
\displaystyle\frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{\cos(x)}{\sin(x)} \right) = \frac{\sin(x)(-\sin(x))-(\cos(x))(\cos(x))}{(\sin(x))^2} = \frac{-1}{(\sin(x))^2} (the original function is cotangent)

exercise.p: Compute the derivative of the following functions:
Compute \frac{dy}{dx} if \ln x + \ln (y^2) = 3.

solution.p: Taking the derivative of both sides of the equation we get \frac 1x + \frac{1}{y^2}\cdot 2y \cdot \frac{dy}{dx} = 0 Solving for \frac{dy}{dx} we get \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{-y}{2x}

There are several approaches here, but let's start with some algebra so that we can get rid of the fraction. y^2(xy-4) = x^2 xy^3-4y^2 = x^2 Taking the derivative of both sides we get x(3y^2)\frac{dy}{dx} + y^3 - 8y\frac{dy}{dx} = 2x Solving for \frac{dy}{dx} we get \frac{dy}{dx}(3xy^2-8y) = 2x-y^3 \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{2x-y^3}{3xy^2-8y} We want to compute the tangent line at (4,2), so we plug in 4 for x and 2 for y. \left. \frac{dy}{dx} \right\vert_{(4,2)} = \frac{2(4)-2^3}{3(4)(2^2)-8(2)} = 0 Since the slope is zero, the tangent line is y=2 as that is the y-coordinate of the point.

exercise.p: Find the slope of the tangent to the curve \sin (xy) = x at the point (1, \pi/2). (Hint: Look at the graph to explain the answer.)

solution.p: First we take the derivative of both sides \cos(xy)\cdot \left( x \frac{dy}{dx}+y\right) = 1 Using algebra to solve for \frac{dy}{dx} we get \frac{dy}{dx} =\frac{\frac{1}{\cos(xy)}-y}{x} Plugging in the point, we get \left. \frac{dy}{dx} \right\vert_{(1,\pi/2)} = \text{ undefined} Looking at the graph you find that the slope is vertical at this point explaining the undefined slope.

exercise.p: Use the tangent line approximation of f(x)=\ln(x) at x=1 to approximate the value \ln(1.1).

solution.p: Using tangent line approximation at x=1 we see that f(1)=\ln(1)=0, f'(x) = \frac 1x, and f'(1) = \frac 11 = 1, so the tangent line is y = f(1)+f'(1)(x-1) = 0 + 1(x-1) = x-1 Using tangent line approximation we see that \ln(1.1) = f(1.1) \approx 1.1-1 = 0.1

exercise.p: Let f(A) represent the price of building a house of area A ft^2 in Bob the Builder's subdivision. To buy a 2100 ft^2 house it costs $200,000. If f'(2100)=90, estimate the cost of a 2150 ft^2 house using tangent line approximation.

solution.p: Using tangent line approximation we get f(A)\approx f(2100)+f'(2100)(A-2100) = 200000+90(A-2100) f(2150)\approx 200000+90(2150-2100) = 204500. The bigger house should cost approximately $204,500.

exercise.p: Let \displaystyle f(x) = \frac{5x}{x^2+4}.

ol.li: Identify the critical points of f.
Find all maxima and minima of f using the first derivative test.
Identify the critical points of g.
Find all maxima and minima of g using the second derivative test.

solution.p: To identify the critical points we take the derivative of g g'(x) = 3x^2-12 = 3(x^2-4)=3(x-2)(x+2) The derivative is zero at x=-2 and x=2. To use the second derivative test we take the second derivative. g''(x) = 6x We then plug in our critical points g''(-2)=-12\quad g''(2)=12 and see there is a local max at x=-2 and a local min at x=2.

exercise.p: adapted from section 4.3A new game is in the process of being invented, and the inventor requests your help in choosing the dimensions of the court it is played on. The court should be rectangular with area 1000\mathrm{ft}^2. There are also 8\mathrm{ft} "out of bounds" zones on the left and right sides, and 5\mathrm{ft} "out of bounds" zones at the top and bottom. Find the dimensions of the smallest area that this court with out of bounds zones could occupy.

Similar to #15 in Section 4.3
The rectangle pictured to the left has one vertex on the graph of the curve y=e^{-x}, one edge along the x-axis, and another edge along the y-axis. Find the value of x that maximizes the area of the rectangle.

section.title: Section 5.1 - How Do We Measure Distance Traveled?

ol.li: Approximate \displaystyle{\int_0^{15} s(t) \,dt} using left and right hand sums with n=5.
What could we do to more accurately approximate \displaystyle{\int_0^{15} s(t) \, dt}?
Give an interpretation of what the value \displaystyle{\int_0^{15} s(t) \, dt} represents in the context of the problem.
To more accurately approximate \displaystyle{\int_0^{15} s(t) \, dt}, we could increase n or look at the average of the left and right hand sums.
The value \displaystyle{\int_0^{15} s(t) \, dt} represents the distance traveled by the runner in those 15 seconds.

exercise.p: Approximate \displaystyle \int_0^{\pi/2} \sin(x) \, dx using n=2 subintervals. (That is, we cut the interval from 0 to \pi/2 into 2 pieces).

solution.p:
\begin{matrix} x \amp 0 \amp \frac{\pi}{4} \amp \frac{\pi}{2} \\ \sin(x) \amp 0 \amp \frac{\sqrt 2}{2} \amp 1 \\ \end{matrix}
Using the left hand sum, right hand sum, and their average we get \text{LHS} = \frac{\pi}{4}\left( 0 + \frac {\sqrt 2} {2} \right) \approx 0.555 \text{RHS} = \frac{\pi}{4}\left( \frac {\sqrt 2} {2} +1 \right) \approx 1.341 \text{Average} = .948 The real value is 1 which is pretty close to the average.

exercise.p: The graph of f(x) is given below.

ol.li: Compute \displaystyle \int_1^3 f(x)\, dx.
Compute \displaystyle \int_0^1 f(x)\, dx.
Compute \displaystyle \int_0^3 f(x)\, dx.
Compute \displaystyle \int_0^3 \vert f(x)\vert \, dx.
\displaystyle \int_1^3 f(x)\, dx = \frac{16}{3}.
\displaystyle \int_0^1 f(x)\, dx = -\frac 56.
\displaystyle \int_0^3 f(x)\, dx = \frac{16}{3}-\frac 56 = \frac{27}{6} = \frac 92.
\displaystyle \int_0^3 \vert f(x)\vert \, dx= \frac{16}{3}-\frac 56 = \frac{37}{6}.

exercise.p: Find all antiderivatives for the following functions:

ol.li: g(t)=\frac{t^2+1}{t}=t+\frac 1t; G(t) = \frac{t^2}{2}+\ln{\vert t \vert}+C

exercise.p: Find the antiderivative F of f(x)=2+4x+5x^2 such that F(0)=0.

solution.p: The general antiderivative looks like F(x) = 2x+2x^2+\frac{5x^3}{3}+C and we want to find the one with F(0)=0. Note that plugging 0 into the above formula yields F(0)=C, hence we need C=0. Our final answer is F(x) = 2x+2x^2+\frac{5x^3}{3} .

Our final answer is thus y = x^2+\ln(|x|)+6.

exercise.p: A rock is thrown straight up from a 45 foot bridge at a velocity of 64 ft/sec.

ol.li: Give formulas for acceleration, velocity, and height of the rock at time t.
When does the rock reach its maximum height?
How high does the rock fly?

li.p: Setting the derivative (velocity) to zero we get
We know it is a maximum by the second derivative test as a(2)=-32.

ol.li: Plugging the time t=2 back into the height function we get h(2) = -16(2)^2+64(2)+45 = 109\text{ feet}

exercise.p: Exercise 12 from Section 4.6A voltage V across a resistance R generates a current
If a constant voltage of $9$ volts is put across a resistance that is increasing at a rate of 0.2 \Omega/sec when the resistance is 5 \Omega, at what rate is the current changing?
A rectangle has one side of 10 cm. How fast is the area of the rectangle changing at the instant when the other side is 12 cm and increasing at 3 cm per minute?

solution.p: Let x be the side length that is changing. We use the area formula to relate the quantities. A=10x. Taking the derivative we get \frac{dA}{dt} = 10 \frac{dx}{dt} = 10(3) = 30 \text{ cm}^2\text{/min}
